<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup';
	}
</script>

	<title>From DarkGate to AsyncRAT: Malware Detected and Shared As Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence</title>

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/trend-reports/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Samantha Stallings"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Brad Duncan"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/samantha-stallings/"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/bduncan/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>

<meta name="post_tags" content="AsyncRAT,BokBot,DarkGate,IcedID,JinxLoader,PikaBot,Remote Access Trojan,Trojan,Wireshark"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/Unit42-timely-threat-intelligence-23-illustration_Blue-wo-logo.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"From DarkGate to AsyncRAT: Malware Detected and Shared As Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence","name":"From DarkGate to AsyncRAT: Malware Detected and Shared As Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence","description":"From October-December, the activities of DarkGate, Pikabot, IcedID and more were seen and shared with the broader community via social media","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup\/","datePublished":"December 29, 2023","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nThis article summarizes the malware families (and groups pushing malware) seen by Unit 42 and shared with the broader threat hunting community through our social channels. Some malware \u2013 such as IcedID and DarkGate \u2013 came up repeatedly. We also included a number of posts about the cybercrime group TA577 \u2013 who have distributed multiple malware families but here favor Pikabot. In other cases, we posted about newer malware such as JinxLoader.\r\n\r\nBy sharing timely threat intelligence via social media channels, we report on malware infections and other threat intelligence of note in an expedited manner. These posts summarize the infection chain, offer helpful screenshots of active traffic and point towards indicators of compromise (IoCs). In 2023, our 93 timely threat intelligence posts in total generated 1.6 million-plus impressions, showing the value of getting IoCs out to the community quickly.\r\n\r\nThis article reviews all our timely threat intelligence released from October through December 2023. Summarizing these threat intelligence posts provides an opportunity to spot trends that are less visible in single posts. We\u2019ve included a table in the Indicators of Compromise section that lists all the posts in full by date posted, name, links to social media channels and IoCs on GitHub.\r\n\r\nMany of these posts contain screenshots of infection traffic filtered in Wireshark, links to the network IoCs and comments linking to packet captures (pcaps) of the associated activity, so this article also provides readers an opportunity to practice and improve their Wireshark skills.\r\n\r\nThe IoCs shared in the social posts are all considered malicious by Palo Alto Networks products. These verdicts are used, for example, by cloud-delivered security services such as Advanced WildFire and Advanced URL Filtering for the Next-Generation Firewall. If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\nTo see our timely threat intelligence posts as we publish them, follow Unit 42 on X and LinkedIn.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nWireshark, Malware, Trojan\r\n\r\n\r\nMalware Families Mentioned\r\nDarkGate, Pikabot, IcedID, AsyncRAT, JinxLoader\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTimely Threat Intelligence\r\nIn addition to the in-depth articles published on this site, Unit 42 also shares timely threat intelligence \u2013 IoCs, TTPs and other observations about active campaigns \u2013 through our social channels.\r\n\r\nUnit 42 shared the first public post about JinxLoader. This information led at least one other vendor, ProofPoint\u2019s Emerging Threats (ET) Labs team, to create a new signature triggering on traffic patterns generated by this malware.\r\n\r\nBesides recapping all social media posts published from October to December, we\u2019ve included a table at the end of this review that includes links to the original posts as well as to all of the IoCs on our GitHub. These original posts include the images from the threat intelligence shared, which range from screen captures of malware and artifacts to the associated traffic filtered in Wireshark. Here we\u2019ll only include the infection chain (as applicable), but head over to X (formerly Twitter) or LinkedIn to review the rest.\r\n\r\nA note: The infection date is not always the same as the date when shared on social channels. The table in the IoCs section includes the posting date. The infection date itself is included in all of the infection chain images. Don\u2019t get confused if you\u2019re comparing the infection date to the posting date and they don\u2019t match up!\r\nTimely Threat Intelligence: October\r\nDarkGate\r\nWe reported on two instances of DarkGate in October. The first instance was DarkGate malware distributed through Microsoft Teams. The attacker posed as the target organization's CEO and sent victims a Teams invite. The message sent contains a password-protected .zip archive. See the entire infection chain below in Figure 1.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131713\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 1. DarkGate infection chain from Microsoft Teams message.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe second instance saw DarkGate malware distributed through fake invoice or billing emails with PDF attachments that spoof DocuSign. Figure 2 illustrates how the process worked. An attentive reader will be able to spot the differences between these two infection chains.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131715\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 2. DarkGate infection chain from email.[\/caption]\r\nPikabot\r\nWe also reported on two instances of Pikabot in October. The first was a Pikabot infection leading to Cobalt Strike HTTPS C2 traffic using zzerxc[.]com on 179.60.149[.]244:443. Figure 3 shows the full series of events.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131717\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 3. Pikabot infection chain.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe second instance saw the cybercrime threat actor TA577 pushing a Pikabot infection with HTTPS Cobalt Strike traffic on 45.155.249[.]171:443 using ponturded[.]com. We\u2019ll definitely see more TA577 activity in this roundup \u2013 the infection chain below in Figure 4 will differ from other TA577 activity.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131719\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 4. Pikabot infection chain.[\/caption]\r\nIcedID (Bokbot)\r\nOur only report in October of banking Trojan IcedID saw a forked variant infection with BackConnect, Anubis VNC, CobaltStrike and ConnectWise ScreenConnect. We also saw \"hands on the keyboard\" approximately 95 minutes after initial infection! Figure 5 lays out how this variant worked.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131721\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 5. IcedID forked variant infection chain.[\/caption]\r\nWS_FTP Server Critical Vulnerability\r\nWe observed multiple attempts to exploit the WS_FTP Server Critical Vulnerability, where threat actors attempted to deliver a Meterpreter payload via the URL 103[.]163.187.12:8080\/cz3eKnhcaD0Fik7Eexo66A. Figure 6 includes not only the infection chain but the command line used.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131723\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"700\"] Figure 6. Infection chain exploiting WS_FTP.[\/caption]\r\nAsyncRAT\r\nA 404 TDS URL chain led to an infection by an AsyncRAT variant. Figure 7 shows the simple infection chain.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131725\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 7. AsyncRAT variant infection chain.[\/caption]\r\nCitrix NetScaler\r\nOctober 2023 saw several indicators of criminals exploiting the Citrix remote-code execution vulnerability CVE-2023-3519. Monitoring this vulnerability in the wild led to a timely snapshot of associated activity. Figure 8 displays the information in a simple column graph. We saw the most detections of this exploit \u2013 over 300 \u2013 from jscloud[.]biz.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131727\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. Snapshot of data from Oct. 17, 2023 showing instances of Citrix RCE vulnerability CVE-2023-3519 in the wild.[\/caption]\r\nTimely Threat Intelligence: November\r\nIcedID\r\nOur first timely threat intelligence post in November saw an IcedID (aka Bokbot) infection from an .msi file. Along with the regular HTTPS C2 traffic, we saw IcedID BackConnect activity on 159.89.124[.]188:443. Note the activity highlighted in red in Figure 9.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131729\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 9. IcedID infection chain stemming from unknown source.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCybercrime group TA577 once more distributed an IcedID (aka Bokbot) variant via a disk image downloaded from an emailed link. Figure 10 illustrates this process. As we continue to review TA577 activity, trends will begin to emerge for analysts to be mindful of.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131731\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 10. Infection chain where cybercrime group TA577 distributes an IcedID variant.[\/caption]\r\nDarkGate\r\nAt least two instances of DarkGate reared their heads in November. In our first sighting, a probable email led the victim to a password-protected .zip file. See it in full with Figure 11.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131776\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 11. DarkGate infection chain stemming from probable email.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe second November appearance of DarkGate also came from an unknown source distributing a password-protected .zip. Comparing and contrasting to the DarkGate activity seen elsewhere in this post shows the variations attackers implement.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131735\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 12. DarkGate infection chain from unknown source.\u00a0[\/caption]\r\nPikabot\r\nA 10-hour infection run led to our list of IoCs from the Pikabot sighting found in November, once more spearheaded by TA577. This infection was from an email and led to a persistent Pikabot DLL. See Figure 13 for the details.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131737\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 13. Infection chain of Pikabot distributed by TA577.[\/caption]\r\nJinxLoader\r\nReportedly named for a League of Legends character, JinxLoader is written in Go. Symantec issued a protection bulletin on JinxLoader just a short while ago. In our post about it (the first public post!) we note that JinxLoader is a relatively new malware service first posted to hackforums[.]net on April 30, 2023. The eight steps of this infection chain are detailed in Figure 14.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131739\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 14. Infection chain of JinxLoader distributing Formbook\/Xloader.[\/caption]\r\nTimely Threat Intelligence: December\r\nLoader EXE\r\nWe started off December by spotting an EXE Loader leading to unidentified malware with C2 using encoded\/encrypted TCP traffic on 91.92.120[.]119:62520. See Figure 15.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131741\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 15. Infection chain of loader to unidentified malware.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWhile one security vendor has identified the loader as \u201cPureLoader\u201d and the unidentified malware as a \u201cPureLogs\u201d stealer, we have seen little else shared publicly on this unidentified malware.\r\nDarkGate\r\nWe reported on one example of DarkGate malware in December 2023. This example was distributed though a PDF file found on VirusTotal. The PDF file has a link that downloaded a malicious ZIP archive for DarkGate. Figure 16 shows a screenshot of the PDF file.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131743\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 16. DarkGate infection from PDF that links to malicious .zip archive.[\/caption]\r\nAstaroth\/Guildma\r\nAstaroth and Guildma may sound like characters from a 1970s pulp sci-fi novel with three moons and blue-skinned aliens on the cover, but they\u2019re actually the name of malware we saw in a Portuguese-language email impersonating Brazil\u2019s State Transport Department (Detran) as shown in Figure 17. This Detran-themed malspam tempted the end user with a link for a zip download \u2013 which is how the Guildma (aka Astaroth) malware infection would start.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131745\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 17. Screenshot of email written in Portuguese that links to malicious download.[\/caption]\r\nPikabot\r\nOur second-to-last report of TA577 in 2023 sees the group distributing Pikabot from an email link. Figure 18 shows the sequence. How does this differ from the previous entries about TA577?\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131747\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"600\"] Figure 18. Infection chain of Pikabot pushed by threat group TA577.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIn the last of our threat intelligence shares for the year (barring additional incidents), we see that, once more, TA577 is spreading a Pikabot infection.\r\n\r\nIn this instance, it led to Cobalt Strike on 207.246.99[.]159:443 using masterunis[.]net as its domain. Figure 19 dissects the traffic.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_131749\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 19. Pikabot malware traffic shown in Wireshark.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nMuch of our timely threat intelligence focuses on Windows malware, and we seek to post on malware families of current interest to the community.\r\n\r\nIf you\u2019re interested in following our updates in real time, follow us on LinkedIn or X (formerly Twitter). If you track hashtags, follow #Unit42ThreatIntel to always catch the latest posts. Another option is to sign up for notifications on our GitHub repo.\r\n\r\nAs soon as you\u2019re in the know, you\u2019re also welcome to participate: comment, share or ask questions.\r\nProtections and Mitigations\r\nThe IoCs shared in the social posts are all considered malicious by Palo Alto Networks products. These verdicts are used, for example, by cloud-delivered security services such as Advanced WildFire and Advanced URL Filtering for the Next-Generation Firewall. If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDate Posted\r\nInfection\r\nLinks\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n10\/03\/2023\r\nWS_FTP vulnerability\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoC available in the posts\u00a0\r\n\r\n\r\n10\/03\/2023\r\nPikabot\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n10\/12\/2023\r\nDarkGate\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n10\/17\/2023\r\nPikabot\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n10\/18\/2023\r\nRCE affecting Citrix NetScaler in the wild\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n10\/20\/2023\r\nIcedID\u00a0\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n10\/23\/2023\r\nAsyncRAT\r\nTwitter (X), to unidentified malware\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n12\/07\/2023\r\nDarkGate\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n12\/12\/2023\r\nAstaroth\/Guildma\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n12\/15\/2023\r\nPikabot\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n12\/18\/2023\r\nPikabot\r\nTwitter (X), LinkedIn\r\nIoCs\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-131710 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    <section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Hactivism_Overview_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
            <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/trend-reports/" role="link" title="Trend Reports" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:hero:breadcrumb:Trend Reports">Trend Reports</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" title="Malware" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:hero:breadcrumb:Malware">Malware</a></li> </ul>

	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">

				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="mailto:?subject=From%20DarkGate%20to%20AsyncRAT:%20Malware%20Detected%20and%20Shared%20As%20Unit%2042%20Timely%20Threat%20Intelligence&#038;body=Check%20out%20this%20article%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-threat-intelligence-roundup%2F" role="link" title="Share in email" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:share:email"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-sms.svg" alt="Link Email"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-threat-intelligence-roundup%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Facebook" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:share:facebook"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-fb-share.svg" alt="Facebook Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-threat-intelligence-roundup%2F&#038;title=From%20DarkGate%20to%20AsyncRAT:%20Malware%20Detected%20and%20Shared%20As%20Unit%2042%20Timely%20Threat%20Intelligence" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in LinkedIn" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:share:linkedin"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-linkedin-share.svg" alt="LinkedIn Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-threat-intelligence-roundup%2F&#038;text=From%20DarkGate%20to%20AsyncRAT:%20Malware%20Detected%20and%20Shared%20As%20Unit%2042%20Timely%20Threat%20Intelligence" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Twitter" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:share:twitter"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-twitter-share.svg" alt="Twitter Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-threat-intelligence-roundup%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=From%20DarkGate%20to%20AsyncRAT:%20Malware%20Detected%20and%20Shared%20As%20Unit%2042%20Timely%20Threat%20Intelligence%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Funit42-threat-intelligence-roundup%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-131710-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>This article summarizes the malware families (and groups pushing malware) seen by Unit 42 and shared with the broader threat hunting community through our social channels. Some malware – such as IcedID and DarkGate – came up repeatedly. We also included a number of posts about the cybercrime group TA577 – who have distributed multiple malware families but here favor Pikabot. In other cases, we posted about newer malware such as JinxLoader.</p>
<p>By sharing timely threat intelligence via social media channels, we report on malware infections and other threat intelligence of note in an expedited manner. These posts summarize the infection chain, offer helpful screenshots of active traffic and point towards indicators of compromise (IoCs). In 2023, our 93 timely threat intelligence posts in total generated 1.6 million-plus impressions, showing the value of getting IoCs out to the community quickly.</p>
<p>This article reviews all our timely threat intelligence released from October through December 2023. Summarizing these threat intelligence posts provides an opportunity to spot trends that are less visible in single posts. We’ve included a table in the <a href="#post-131710-_v8176g40kstn">Indicators of Compromise</a> section that lists all the posts in full by date posted, name, links to social media channels and IoCs on GitHub.</p>
<p>Many of these posts contain screenshots of infection traffic filtered in Wireshark, links to the network IoCs and comments linking to packet captures (pcaps) of the associated activity, so this article also provides readers an opportunity to practice and improve their Wireshark skills.</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The IoCs shared in the social posts are all considered malicious by Palo Alto Networks products. These verdicts are used, for example, by </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions"><span style="font-weight: 400;">cloud-delivered security services</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> such as </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced WildFire</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced URL Filtering</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for the </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Next-Generation Firewall</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the </span><a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unit 42 Incident Response team</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></p>
<p>To see our timely threat intelligence posts as we publish them, follow Unit 42 on <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel" target="_blank" rel="noopener">X</a> and <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/company/unit42" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LinkedIn</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/wireshark/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Wireshark</a>, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Malware</a>, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/trojan/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trojan</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Malware Families Mentioned</b></td>
<td>DarkGate, Pikabot, IcedID, AsyncRAT, JinxLoader</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2>Timely Threat Intelligence</h2>
<p>In addition to the in-depth articles published on this site, Unit 42 also shares timely threat intelligence – IoCs, TTPs and other observations about active campaigns – through our social channels.</p>
<p>Unit 42 shared the <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1730237085246775562" target="_blank" rel="noopener">first public post about JinxLoader</a>. This information led at least one other vendor, ProofPoint’s <a href="https://linktr.ee/et_labs" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Emerging Threats (ET) Labs</a> team, to create a new signature triggering on traffic patterns generated by this malware.</p>
<p>Besides recapping all social media posts published from October to December, we’ve included <a href="#post-131710-_v8176g40kstn">a table</a> at the end of this review that includes links to the original posts as well as to all of the IoCs on our GitHub. These original posts include the images from the threat intelligence shared, which range from screen captures of malware and artifacts to the associated traffic filtered in Wireshark. Here we’ll only include the infection chain (as applicable), but head over to X (formerly Twitter) or LinkedIn to review the rest.</p>
<p>A note: The infection date is not always the same as the date when shared on social channels. The table in the IoCs section includes the posting date. The infection date itself is included in all of the infection chain images. Don’t get confused if you’re comparing the infection date to the posting date and they don’t match up!</p>
<h2><a id="post-131710-_i71cu1pi4jp"></a>Timely Threat Intelligence: October</h2>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_djjd701k52qb"></a>DarkGate</h3>
<p>We reported on two instances of <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.darkgate" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DarkGate</a> in October. The <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1712612195651998098" target="_blank" rel="noopener">first instance</a> was DarkGate malware distributed through Microsoft Teams. The attacker posed as the target organization's CEO and sent victims a Teams invite. The message sent contains a password-protected .zip archive. See the entire infection chain below in Figure 1.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131713" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131713" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131713" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-1.jpeg" alt="2023-10-12 (Thursday) DarkGate from Teams message. Diagram of the distribution of the malware. Teams chat invite and message &gt; password-protected zip archive from Teams chat &gt; extracted Windows shortcut &gt; PowerShell commands from shortcut &gt; HTTP traffic &gt; Autolt3.exe runs .au3 file &gt; HTTP traffic for encoded binary &gt; encoded binary converted to DarkGate EXE &gt; DarkGate HTTP C2 traffic" width="600" height="349" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131713" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. DarkGate infection chain from Microsoft Teams message.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1717687387025809465" target="_blank" rel="noopener">second instance</a> saw DarkGate malware distributed through fake invoice or billing emails with PDF attachments that spoof DocuSign. Figure 2 illustrates how the process worked. An attentive reader will be able to spot the differences between these two infection chains.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131715" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131715" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131715" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-2.jpeg" alt="2023-10-25 (Wed) DarkGate from email. billing/invoice-themed email &gt; attached PDF &gt; link from PDF &gt; downloaded .cab &gt; extracted URL from shortcut file &gt; web traffic for zip-ed.msi file &gt; .msi installs Autoit3.exe and .au3 file &gt; .au3 file contains XOR-encoded EXE &gt; infection generates DarkGate HTTP C2 traffic" width="600" height="327" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131715" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. DarkGate infection chain from email.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_vr4lyxej10rz"></a>Pikabot</h3>
<p>We also reported on two instances of <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.pikabot" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Pikabot</a> in October. The <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1709327580380197038c" target="_blank" rel="noopener">first was a Pikabot infection</a> leading to Cobalt Strike HTTPS C2 traffic using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">zzerxc[.]com</span> on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">179.60.149[.]244:443</span>. Figure 3 shows the full series of events.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131717" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131717" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131717" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-3.jpeg" alt="Pikabot infection with Cobalt Strike. Thread-hijacked email &gt; link from email &gt; password-protected zip archive &gt; extracted Windows shortcut &gt; URL for Pikabot DLL &gt; Pikabot installer DLL &gt; HTTPS C2 traffic from Pikabot &gt; Follow-up activity: Cobalt Strike" width="600" height="321" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131717" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Pikabot infection chain.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1714375817491353966" target="_blank" rel="noopener">second instance</a> saw the <a href="https://bazaar.abuse.ch/browse/tag/ta577/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">cybercrime threat actor TA577</a> pushing a Pikabot infection with HTTPS Cobalt Strike traffic on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">45.155.249[.]171:443</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ponturded[.]com</span>. We’ll definitely see more TA577 activity in this roundup – the infection chain below in Figure 4 will differ from other TA577 activity.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131719" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131719" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131719" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-4.jpeg" alt="2023.10.17 (Thurs). email --&gt; link for zip download --&gt; downloaded zip --&gt; extracted .js file --&gt; retrieves and runs Pikabot installer DLL --&gt; Pikabot C2 --&gt; Cobalt Strike " width="600" height="311" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131719" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Pikabot infection chain.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_wl6kdw6se0kb"></a>IcedID (Bokbot)</h3>
<p>Our only report in October of <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1715348477809402118" target="_blank" rel="noopener">banking Trojan IcedID</a> saw a forked variant infection with <a href="https://www.team-cymru.com/post/inside-the-icedid-backconnect-protocol" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BackConnect</a>, <a href="https://blog.nviso.eu/2023/03/20/icedids-vnc-backdoors-dark-cat-anubis-keyhole/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anubis VNC</a>, CobaltStrike and ConnectWise <a href="https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hackers-breach-healthcare-orgs-via-screenconnect-remote-access/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ScreenConnect</a>. We also saw "hands on the keyboard" approximately 95 minutes after initial infection! Figure 5 lays out how this variant worked.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131721" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131721" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131721" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-5.jpeg" alt="2023-10-18 (Wed) IcedID forked variant with BackConnect, Anubis VNC, Cobalt Strike and ScreenConnect. URL and redirects &gt; ZIP &gt; VBS file &gt; DLL &gt; HTTP traffic &gt; persistent DLL &gt; HTTPS C2 traffic from IcedID forked variant &gt; Follow-up activity" width="600" height="349" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131721" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. IcedID forked variant infection chain.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_h6tee1bdp5hy"></a>WS_FTP Server Critical Vulnerability</h3>
<p>We observed multiple attempts to exploit the <a href="https://community.progress.com/s/article/WS-FTP-Server-Critical-Vulnerability-September-2023" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WS_FTP Server Critical Vulnerability</a>, where threat actors attempted to <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1709241972001583430" target="_blank" rel="noopener">deliver a Meterpreter payload</a> via the URL <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">103[.]163.187.12:8080/cz3eKnhcaD0Fik7Eexo66A</span>. Figure 6 includes not only the infection chain but the command line used.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131723" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131723" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131723" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-6.jpeg" alt="&quot;WS_ FTP Exploitation - RCE under the w3wp.exe process &gt; Obfuscated PowerShell Loads shellcode &gt; Certutil Command &gt; Meterpreter Payload - FaNXrikucf.exe. Certutil command line is included. &quot;" width="700" height="317" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131723" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Infection chain exploiting WS_FTP.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_62yjkxi1kks2"></a>AsyncRAT</h3>
<p>A <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1717179793966268785" target="_blank" rel="noopener">404 TDS URL chain</a> led to an infection by an <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.asyncrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AsyncRAT</a> variant. Figure 7 shows the simple infection chain.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131725" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131725" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131725" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-7.jpeg" alt="2023-10-23 (Mon): 404 TDS URL chain leads to Async RAT variant. Initial URL &gt; 404 TDS redirect URL &gt; .js file download URL &gt; downloaded .js file &gt; victim double-clicks .js file &gt; Async RAT variant infection" width="600" height="254" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131725" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. AsyncRAT variant infection chain.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_6iqbwm5gp7u0"></a>Citrix NetScaler</h3>
<p>October 2023 saw several indicators of criminals exploiting the <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-brief-citrix-cve-2023-3519/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Citrix remote-code execution vulnerability CVE-2023-3519</a>. Monitoring this vulnerability in the wild led to a timely <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1714691618656161952" target="_blank" rel="noopener">snapshot of associated activity</a>. Figure 8 displays the information in a simple column graph. We saw the most detections of this exploit – over 300 – from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jscloud[.]biz</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131727" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131727" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131727" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-8.jpeg" alt="Column chart of count of in the wild instances of injected domains " width="900" height="560" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131727" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Snapshot of data from Oct. 17, 2023 showing instances of Citrix RCE vulnerability CVE-2023-3519 in the wild.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-131710-_m7hx2qcha675"></a>Timely Threat Intelligence: November</h2>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_iosp43cm1xs5"></a>IcedID</h3>
<p>Our <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1719841834204033376" target="_blank" rel="noopener">first timely threat intelligence post</a> in November saw an IcedID (aka Bokbot) infection from an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.msi</span> file. Along with the regular HTTPS C2 traffic, we saw IcedID BackConnect activity on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">159.89.124[.]188:443</span>. Note the activity highlighted in red in Figure 9.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131729" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131729" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131729" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-9.jpeg" alt="IcedID (BokBot) activity. Unknown source &gt; Microsoft Installer (MSI) package &gt; IcedID installer DLL &gt; HTTP traffic for fake gzip binary &gt; license.dat and persistent IcedID DLL created from fake gzip binary &gt; IcedID HTTP C2 activity and BackConnect traffic. " width="600" height="346" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131729" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. IcedID infection chain stemming from unknown source.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Cybercrime group TA577 <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7135285478743822336/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">once more distributed</a> an IcedID (aka Bokbot) variant via a disk image downloaded from an emailed link. Figure 10 illustrates this process. As we continue to review TA577 activity, trends will begin to emerge for analysts to be mindful of.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131731" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131731" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131731" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-10.jpeg" alt="infection chain: email &gt; victim clicks link from email &gt; downloads disk image &gt; victim, double clicks disk image to mount and open it &gt; victim double clicks the windows shortcut, which runs hidden DLL for IcedID variant &gt; HTTPS C2 post-infection traffic" width="600" height="345" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131731" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Infection chain where cybercrime group TA577 distributes an IcedID variant.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_i0zmgydex6tr"></a>DarkGate</h3>
<p>At least two instances of DarkGate reared their heads in November. In our <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7132871065139126272/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">first sighting</a>, a probable email led the victim to a password-protected <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> file. See it in full with Figure 11.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131776" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131776" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131776" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/Fig-11-Probable.png" alt="2023-11-20 (Monday) - DarkGate from Probable Email: link for password-protected .zip file &gt; password-protected .zip file &gt; Windows shortcut file &gt; web traffic for initial DarkGate files &gt; copy of Autoit3 EXE runs DarkGate .au3 file &gt; DarkGate C2 traffic" width="600" height="346" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131776" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. DarkGate infection chain stemming from probable email.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The second November <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7136107639616274432/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">appearance of DarkGate</a> also came from an unknown source distributing a password-protected <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span>. Comparing and contrasting to the DarkGate activity seen elsewhere in this post shows the variations attackers implement.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131735" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131735" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131735" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-12.jpeg" alt="Unknown source&gt;password-protected zip archive&gt;extracted Windows shortcuts&gt;HTTP traffic for HTA file&gt;host runs HTA file in background&gt;HTTP for Lightspeed EXE and malicious DLL&gt;Lightspeed EXE sideloads malicious DLL&gt;DLL drops, runs EXE and AU3 file&gt;DarkGate" width="600" height="338" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131735" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. DarkGate infection chain from unknown source.<span style="font-size: 16px;"> </span></figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_4822p56cj57l"></a>Pikabot</h3>
<p>A 10-hour infection run led to our list of IoCs from the <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1720507470290801122" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Pikabot sighting found in November</a>, once more spearheaded by TA577. This infection was from an email and led to a persistent Pikabot DLL. See Figure 13 for the details.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131737" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131737" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131737" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-13.jpeg" alt="2023-11-02 (Thurs) TA577 PikaBot Actvity. Email&gt;Link from email&gt;Downloaded ZIP&gt;Extracted JS file&gt;URL for PikaBot installer DLL&gt;PikaBot installer DLL is run&gt;Persistent PikaBot DLL&gt;HTTPS C2 traffic from PikaBot" width="600" height="311" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131737" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Infection chain of Pikabot distributed by TA577.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_iz60c8uj1rks"></a>JinxLoader</h3>
<p>Reportedly named for a League of Legends character, JinxLoader is written in Go. Symantec issued a <a href="https://www.broadcom.com/support/security-center/protection-bulletin#blt659864ea768c848a_en-us" target="_blank" rel="noopener">protection bulletin on JinxLoader</a> just a short while ago. In <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1730237085246775562" target="_blank" rel="noopener">our post</a> about it (the first public post!) we note that JinxLoader is a relatively new malware service first posted to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hackforums[.]net</span> on April 30, 2023. The eight steps of this infection chain are detailed in Figure 14.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131739" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131739" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131739" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/attack-chain-emailgreater-password-protected-rar-archiv.jpeg" alt="Attack chain: email&gt; password protected RAR archive&gt; extracted ZIP archive&gt;JinxLoader EXE&gt; HTTPS traffic for XOR-encoded DLL&gt;IP address checks&gt;JinxLoader check-in traffic starts&gt;Formbook/Xloader C2 traffic starts" width="600" height="347" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131739" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Infection chain of JinxLoader distributing Formbook/Xloader.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-131710-_pcb14lfeyfnv"></a>Timely Threat Intelligence: December</h2>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_gfrod5mzhpbg"></a>Loader EXE</h3>
<p>We started off December by <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7138177278936567808/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">spotting an EXE Loader</a> leading to unidentified malware with C2 using encoded/encrypted TCP traffic on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">91.92.120[.]119:62520</span>. See Figure 15.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131741" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131741" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131741" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-15.jpeg" alt="2023.12.5 Tues Infection Chain: Loader to unidentified malware. Email&gt;attached disk image&gt;extracted EXE&gt;HTTPS traffic for reverse byte order DLL&gt;encrypted or encoded TCP traffic." width="600" height="236" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131741" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Infection chain of loader to unidentified malware.</figcaption></figure>
<p>While <a href="https://twitter.com/Jane_0sint/status/1732499926997733655" target="_blank" rel="noopener">one security vendor</a> has identified the loader as “PureLoader” and the unidentified malware as a “PureLogs” stealer, we have seen little else shared publicly on this unidentified malware.</p>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_71f2ymrrgku1"></a>DarkGate</h3>
<p>We reported on one example of DarkGate malware in December 2023. This example was distributed though a PDF file found on VirusTotal. The PDF file has a link that downloaded a malicious ZIP archive for DarkGate. Figure 16 shows a screenshot of the PDF file.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131743" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131743" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131743" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-16.jpeg" alt="Screenshot of Adobe Acrobat. Red open button goes to URL indicated by arrow. Next, file downloads from OneDrive. Arrow points to zip file Passport2021023_90223.pdf.zip. " width="900" height="499" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131743" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. DarkGate infection from PDF that links to malicious <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.zip</span> archive.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_jm3v583eelmv"></a>Astaroth/Guildma</h3>
<p>Astaroth and Guildma may sound like characters from a 1970s pulp sci-fi novel with three moons and blue-skinned aliens on the cover, but they’re <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7140451769850970113/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">actually the name of malware</a> we saw in a Portuguese-language email impersonating Brazil’s State Transport Department (Detran) as shown in Figure 17. This Detran-themed malspam tempted the end user with a link for a zip download – which is how the Guildma (aka Astaroth) malware infection would start.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131745" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131745" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131745" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-17.jpeg" alt="Screenshot of email in Mozilla Thunderbird. The language is Portuguese. The blue CONSULTAR button links to the text in red. " width="900" height="850" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131745" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. Screenshot of email written in Portuguese that links to malicious download.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_12bh8jqdjk0v"></a>Pikabot</h3>
<p>Our second-to-last report of TA577 in 2023 sees the group <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1735760477391552670" target="_blank" rel="noopener">distributing Pikabot</a> from an email link. Figure 18 shows the sequence. How does this differ from the previous entries about TA577?</p>
<figure id="attachment_131747" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131747" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131747" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-18.jpeg" alt="TA557 Pikabot infection chain: Email&gt;link from email&gt;downloaded .zip&gt;extracted JavaScript file&gt;URLs for Pikabot installer DLL&gt;Pikabot installer DLL is run&gt;Pikabot HTTPS C2 traffic" width="600" height="360" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131747" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 18. Infection chain of Pikabot pushed by threat group TA577.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the last of our threat intelligence shares for the year (barring additional incidents), we see that, <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1736859404157276596" target="_blank" rel="noopener">once more, TA577</a> is spreading a Pikabot infection.</p>
<p>In this instance, it led to Cobalt Strike on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">207.246.99[.]159:443</span> using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">masterunis[.]net</span> as its domain. Figure 19 dissects the traffic.</p>
<figure id="attachment_131749" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-131749" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-131749" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/word-image-131710-19.png" alt="Wireshark traffic. From top down: Initial zip. Pikabot DLL. Pikabot C2. Cobalt Strike traffic starts. " width="900" height="445" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-131749" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 19. Pikabot malware traffic shown in Wireshark.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-131710-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Much of our timely threat intelligence focuses on Windows malware, and we seek to post on malware families of current interest to the community.</span></p>
<p>If you’re interested in following our updates in real time, follow us on <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/company/10052935/admin/feed/posts/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LinkedIn</a> or <a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel" target="_blank" rel="noopener">X (formerly Twitter)</a>. If you track hashtags, follow #Unit42ThreatIntel to always catch the latest posts. Another option is to sign up for notifications on our <a href="https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/Unit42-timely-threat-intel" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GitHub repo</a>.</p>
<p>As soon as you’re in the know, you’re also welcome to participate: comment, share or ask questions.</p>
<h3><a id="post-131710-_mxauz7lzdss6"></a>Protections and Mitigations</h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The IoCs shared in the social posts are all considered malicious by Palo Alto Networks products. These verdicts are used, for example, by </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions"><span style="font-weight: 400;">cloud-delivered security services</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> such as </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced WildFire</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced URL Filtering</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for the </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Next-Generation Firewall</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the </span><a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unit 42 Incident Response team</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></p>

</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">12/12/2023</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Astaroth/Guildma</span></td>
<td><a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1734686148289777666" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Twitter (X)</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7140451769850970113" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">LinkedIn</span></a></td>
<td><a href="https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/Unit42-timely-threat-intel/blob/main/2023-12-11-IOCs-for-Astaroth-Guildma-activity.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">IoCs</span></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">12/15/2023</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Pikabot</span></td>
<td><a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1735760477391552670" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Twitter (X)</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:ugcPost:7141526097799659522/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">LinkedIn</span></a></td>
<td><a href="https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/Unit42-timely-threat-intel/blob/main/2023-12-15-IOCs-for-TA577-Pikabot-infection.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">IoCs</span></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">12/18/2023</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Pikabot</span></td>
<td><a href="https://twitter.com/Unit42_Intel/status/1736859404157276596" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Twitter (X)</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:share:7142625077468028928/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">LinkedIn</span></a></td>
<td><a href="https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/Unit42-timely-threat-intel/blob/main/2023-12-18-IOCs-for-Pikabot-with-Cobalt-Strike.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">IoCs</span></a></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-131710-_by5ncs8ou2e9"></a><br />
Additional Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Malware Traffic Analysis.net</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/wireshark-tutorial/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Wireshark Tutorials</a> – Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/Unit42-timely-threat-intel" target="_blank" rel="noopener">IoCs of Unit 42 Timely Threat Intelligence</a> – GitHub</li>
<li><a href="https://twitter.com/ET_Labs/status/1730738248601817526" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SID 2049408 by Emerging Threats Labs</a> – X (Twitter)</li>
<li><a href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/12/new-malvertising-campaign-distributing.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">New Malvertising Campaign Distributing PikaBot Disguised as Popular Software</a> – The Hacker News</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/08_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A pictorial representation of a red team tool like Splinter.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/analysis-pentest-tool-splinter/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/red-teaming-tool/" title="red teaming tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:red teaming tool">Red teaming tool</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/pentest-tool/" title="pentest tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="unit42-threat-intelligence-roundup:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:pentest tool">Pentest tool</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
